primary: Aéroport Chambéry Savoie Mont Blanc official website
French DGAC (Direction Générale de l'Aviation Civile)

operational_hours.notes: Business Terminal: 09:30-18:30 weekdays, 09:00-18:00 weekends/holidays (winter: 07:30-21:00). Control tower active 07:00-20:00 UTC.

slot_requirements.slot_availability_typical: Slots required for all operations; availability generally good except peak ski season
slot_requirements.peak_congestion_times: December-February (ski season), July-August (summer holiday), Easter period
slot_requirements.notes: Alpine aviation procedures require close coordination with ATC. Handling is mandatory.

weather_vulnerability.snow_closure_frequency: Frequent December-March - average 2-3 closure days per month during peak winter
weather_vulnerability.wind_limitations: Strong mountain winds common; wind warnings can restrict operations
weather_vulnerability.cat_capability: Category I ILS available on runways 18 and 36
weather_vulnerability.weather_patterns: Alpine continental climate. Heavy winter snowfall (200-300cm annually at airport). Spring thaw creates avalanche risk. Afternoon thunderstorms common summer.
weather_vulnerability.fog_characteristics: Valley fog common in early morning and evening, particularly November-February
weather_vulnerability.wind_characteristics: Föhn winds (warm, dry mountain winds) can exceed 60 km/h; valley wind funneling effects

runway_specifications.crosswind_limitations: Variable - mountain terrain effects on wind pattern
runway_specifications.weight_restrictions: No published restrictions but mountainous terrain limits very large aircraft
runway_specifications.notes: Relatively short runway for international operations. Alpine terrain requires precise approaches.

crew_requirements.minimum_pilot_hours: Mountain flying experience mandatory; specific Alpine certification recommended
crew_requirements.alpine_procedures: Mandatory familiarity with French Alpine flying procedures and terrain avoidance techniques
crew_requirements.notes: EASA FCL.815 mountain rating requirements apply. Pilots unfamiliar with Alpine operations should arrange ground training. Special approach procedures for terrain clearance.

handling_complexity.weekend_surcharges: Yes - premium rates for weekend/holiday operations
handling_complexity.notes: Mandatory handling. Limited FBO services compared to major airports. Winter operations require specific ground support arrangements.
handling_complexity.winter_considerations: Snow removal services available; de-icing coordination required in advance

congestion_metrics.airspace_complexity: Medium-High - Alpine terrain requires precise navigation
congestion_metrics.notes: Ski season (Dec-Feb) creates 3x normal traffic. Small airport can quickly exceed capacity. Summer tourism creates secondary peak.

permits_and_clearances.notes: PPR required for all operations. Alpine procedures briefing may be required for unfamiliar crews.
permits_and_clearances.special_approvals: Mountain flying certification verification may be requested

noise_restrictions.preferred_departure_routes: Mountain departure procedures established per Alpine aviation guidelines
noise_restrictions.noise_complaints_risk: Low-Medium - small airport with few noise-sensitive areas
noise_restrictions.notes: Noise less significant issue than at larger airports. Alpine procedures inherently minimize ground noise.

infrastructure_reliability.winter_reliability: Generally reliable but heavy snow can temporarily affect operations

security_requirements.notes: Standard EU security protocols. Small airport provides expedited processing.

seasonal_factors.ski_season_congestion: Extreme - December-February peak tourism to local ski resorts
seasonal_factors.notes: Ski season creates primary operational challenge. Winter weather can cause multi-day closures. Summer relatively quiet except holidays.

backup_alternates.name: Grenoble Alpes-Isère
backup_alternates.notes: Closer alternative but smaller, limited services

alternate_airport_proximity.notes: Geneva is preferred alternate with better facilities and reliability. Lyon offers international connections. All alternates in moderate to high-altitude terrain.

payment_and_fees.handling_agent_prepayment: Often required for fuel and ground services
payment_and_fees.fuel_payment_terms: Post-flight settlement available with handling agent coordination
payment_and_fees.landing_fees: Yes - based on aircraft weight and operation type
payment_and_fees.parking_fees: Yes - hourly rates, Alpine weather surcharges apply in winter
payment_and_fees.winter_surcharges: Yes - additional charges for snow removal and de-icing services
payment_and_fees.notes: Payment methods through handling agents; credit cards accepted. DGAC maintains published tariff schedule.

primary_challenges: Alpine terrain requires specialized crew training
Limited runway length for large aircraft
Mountain weather makes CAT II/III rating essential
Limited ground services compared to major airports
operational_advantages: Mountain scenery and low traffic outside peak season
Generally efficient operations when weather permits
summary.crew_considerations: Mandatory: Alpine mountain flying certification, CAT II/III rating essential. Pre-flight Alpine procedures briefing recommended. Experience with terrain-following procedures required.
summary.planning_recommendation: Book minimum 48-72 hours advance. Verify Alpine crew certifications in crew requirements. Winter season (Dec-Feb) requires extra attention to weather forecasting and de-icing arrangements. Summer operations (Jul-Aug) more predictable. Always have Geneva or Lyon as backup alternate. Monitor mountain weather closely.
